page.title: 12THE LANCASTER CANAL-HISTORY.
page.content: The Lancaster Canal originally went from Preston to Kendal, passing through the city of Lancaster. Plans to build the canal were formed in 1792 for three reasons. Firstly,transporting coal from South Lancashire northwards, secondly, bringing produce from the farmlands to the coal field and finally as a boost to the trade of Lancaster. The building of the canal was organised by John Rennie,but much of it was carried out by William Cartwright. Building it was a big job, all the bed was lined with clay, there were bridges and aqueducts to build,and some,but not many locks. All the work was done by hand, there were no mechanical tools. Commercial traffic on the canal ceased in 1947 and since then about 10 miles at the north end have been abandoned. This caused much controversy in 1965.
